**Output:**

Prehistory is the time before written records. It starts from the beginning of the universe and ends around 3500 years ago. During this time, humans and animals lived on Earth, but we don't have books or papers to tell us about them. We learn about prehistory by studying fossils, bones, and tools that people made. Archaeologists, scientists who study old things, help us understand this time. They find and examine these items to learn about how people and animals lived long ago. This helps us understand our past and how we've changed over time.

**Final Paragraph:**

Prehistory is the time before people started writing. It starts with the first humans and ends when writing begins. This period is over 3 million years long. During prehistory, people didn't have modern tools or technology. They used simple tools made from stone, wood, and bone. They lived in small groups, hunting animals and gathering plants for food. They also created art, like cave paintings. Archaeologists study this time by finding and examining old tools, bones, and other remains. This helps us understand how early humans lived and how they evolved.

Prehistory is the time before written records, when humans had no way to write down their history. It starts with the first humans around 2.6 million years ago and ends with the invention of writing, which varies by culture but was around 3400 BC in Mesopotamia. During this time, people lived as hunters and gatherers, using tools made of stone or bone. They traveled in small groups, following animals or plants for food. Prehistory is studied through archaeology, which uses clues from the past like tools, art, and buildings to understand how people lived.

**Output:**

Prehistory is the time before written records. It started when humans first appeared on Earth, about 6 million years ago. During this time, humans did not write books or keep records. They lived as hunters and gatherers, relying on nature for food and shelter. They made tools from stones, bones, and other materials. Over time, they learned to make better tools and use fire. This helped them survive and spread across the world. Archaeologists study prehistory by finding and examining these tools and other artifacts. They also study the bones and remains of animals that lived during this time. By doing this, they can learn about how humans and animals lived long ago.

**Final Paragraph:**

"Prehistory is the time before written records. It starts from the beginning of life on Earth until people began to write things down. This period is very long, over three million years! We can learn about prehistory by studying fossils, tools, and other signs left behind by early humans and animals. Scientists call these signs 'evidence.' By looking at this evidence, we can understand how life on Earth has changed over time."

In the far past, before people could write, there was a time called prehistory. This was when our earliest human ancestors lived on Earth. They didn't have books, so we don't have their stories. We learn about them through fossils and tools they left behind. This time is important because it helps us understand how humans first started living and working together. It also shows how we began using tools and changing our world.
